Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Algorithms for Markets, Games and their Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last few years, some of the most interesting questions in the theory of algorithms have come up in designing mechanisms for selfish users especially in the context of the Internet. The Internet itself is
comprised of several autonomous entities with varying sizes and interests. It has also given birth to several online market places and electronic commerce applications in which several businesses sell, buy and trade in real time.

This research involves designing algorithms or protocols that can be implemented in these multi-agent settings. In particular, the PI will focus on computing central solution concepts developed in game theory
such as market equilibria, Nash equilibria, and the core of cooperative games. The PI will also apply these algorithms in designing online market places. In particular, the PI will study adwords and other
similar auctions used by search engines for selling advertisement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI studied the computational complexity of market equlibria, Nash equilibria and other game theoretic solution concepts. Such algorithms have applications in simulating market dynamics, measuring the effect of various market policies, and the design of new markets especially on the world wide web.

In particular, the PI and co-authors studied online auctions used by Google, Microsoft, and other web publishers for allocating online advertisement space. They considered a simplified model where the publisher receives the bids of advertisers and their maximum budget for a certain period (e.g. a day or a week). As users visit the site, the publisher assigns the ad space next to the content presented to the user to advertisers and charges them the value of their bid for the impression of the ad. PI and co-authors studied these markets and designed new algorithms that improve the efficiency of the market. 

The PI also developed new algorithms for classic optimization problems especially traveling salesman problems. For example, the PI (and co-authors) offered a new approximation algorithm for the asymmetric traveling salesman problem improving the best-known approximation bound after over thirty years. This was possible due to the development of a new technique for rounding the solution of a linear program using sampling.
